paragraphs.text: The Observer view on our health and the sugar-peddling food industry.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The London Eye, a landmark since the Millennium, welcomed the first day of a new sponsor yesterday
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Coca-Cola plans to play "an even greater part in future moments of happiness and celebration in the capital", according to Jon Woods, general manager of Coca-Cola UK and Ireland
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It's ironic that the arrival of the red and white trademark colours of a global drink renowned, in its original form, for providing a shocking nine spoonfuls of sugar per 330ml can, comes at the end of a week in which, as in every week, 500 children received hospital treatment for dental decay
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there have been a stream of warnings about the health of the nation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We are swallowing far more sugar, salt and fat than is good for us- or the public purse
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One warning came last Thursday
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when On Rock or Sand: Firm Foundations for Britain's Future was published, edited by John Sentamu, archbishop of York
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It tackles a range of issues spawned by a low-wage economy and refers to the current epidemic of obesity that, for the first time in many decades, means that some children may live shorter lives than their parents
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On Rock or Sand rightly points out that "choice" in diet is complex
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It is influenced by income, class, culture and societal pressure among myriad other drivers, not least the seductive practices of the marketplace in disguising what goes into processed food and employing the hard sell in honeyed words that are particularly effective on children
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Low-cost food and medical progress have ensured longer lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: decades with a long-term condition can also bring misery
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The book quotes Department of Health figures that show 62% of adults and 28% of children are overweight or obese
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The health problems this spawns include type 2 diabetes, cancer and heart disease, between them costing NHS England more than? 5bn a year
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Last Wednesday, Andy Burnham, Labour shadow health secretary, launched Labour's public health strategy
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It served up even scarier statistics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Unless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the rise in obesity is reversed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the cost to the NHS of diabetes alone will rise from ? 10bn a year to an unsustainable ? 17bn a year by 2035
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the World Health Organisation recommends that 5% of our food energy should come from sugar
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: children are consuming triple that amount
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Further bad news came from the Youth Sport Trust, in its Unlocking Potential report
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Only 21% of boys and 16% of girls are exercising sufficiently
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Physical education lessons have slumped below the miserly two hours a week set by the previous Labour government
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The trust is rightly calling for five hours of physical activity a week in state schools to match that offered by private schools
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Eating too much and doing too little may be a personal "choice" for some
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's one the nation can ill-afford
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So what's to be done?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The first is to show common sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is incredible that Merlin Entertainments should consider Coca-Cola a suitable sponsor for the London Eye
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As this paper reports, John Middleton, vice-president of the UK Faculty of Public Health, says:"Coca-Cola is the flagship for sugar marketing and therefore the flagship for rotten teeth and diabetes."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The second imperative is for government to wake up to the scale of the health disaster on its doorstep
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In February 2010, David Cameron laid out his vision for "a new age of government"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "If you combine this very simple, very conservative thought - go with the grain of human nature- with all the advances in behavioural economics," he said,"I think we can achieve a real increase in wellbeing... without necessarily having to spend a lot of money."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Money has certainly been tight
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: even as public health issues, supporting improved wellbeing, have disastrously dropped off the agenda, issues such as plain packages for cigarettes, minimum pricing on alcohol and an end to selling sports fields
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In 2013-14, the NHS budget was over ? 95bn, compared with only ? 1.8 bn allocated to Public Health England to promote "wellness"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The lack of investment in prevention, married to politicians' fear of the charge of "uber-interference" and "the nanny state", means that multinationals have too little restraint
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We accept the so-called nanny state edicts on seat belts, smoking and drink
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: why can't the state take a much greater role in improving the food that is sold to us and marketed to our children?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Andy Burnham calls this "finger wagging"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: On the contrary
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is lifesaving
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is welcome that Burnham has promised that Labour will legislate to reduce the sugar, fat and salt in foods sold to children
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Such steps require rigour in the face of food industry claims that it's difficult to differentiate between "family foods"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The "responsibility deal" in which businesses voluntarily take action to improve public health hasn't produced many results
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last week, for instance, Asda promised to reduce 22% of added sugar in some 26 of its own brand drinks, amounting to a reduction of a staggering 3.25bn calories
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Professor Graham MacGregor of Action on Sugar says that only reveals the scale of what remains to be done
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Little bits of action are no substitute for sugar reduction mandated by government policy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As Burnham correctly said last week:"For change to work in a market context, all players need to be following the same rules."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Dame Sally Davies, the chief medical officer, has warned that a 20% tax on sugar in fizzy drinks may be required
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It makes sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Advertising to children is another issue requiring intervention
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Promoting unhealthy products is restricted on children's television
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is unfettered online in "advergames" and between 8pm and 9pm on television
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when, according to Malcolm Clark of the lobbying group, the Children's Food Campaign (CFC), ads are a junk food paradise
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Burnham intends to ask the committee on advertising practice and the Advertising Standards Authority how children can be better protected
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That is a cop-out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The CFC, backed by the British Heart Foundation, has rightly proposed a body independent from the advertising industry to monitor and regulate marketing to children and tougher enforcements
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Managing diet, taking exercise and aiming for fitness can't be directly stipulated in law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Parents, government, the community and the commercial sector all play a part in taking responsibility
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the balance of power is skewed against the ordinary citizen, particularly those penalised by profound health inequalities, and towards those with profit in mind
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The state has to play a far more dynamic role than Labour envisages or the coalition provides, to ensure that what does us good, at a price we can afford, becomes the established framework for a healthy life
paragraphs.label: assumption
